div.p: THE REFVSERS OF PEACE UNEXCUSABLE.
IN ANSWER TO A LIBELL AGAINST HIS MAIESTIES LATE MESSAGES FOR PEACE.
OXFORD, Printed by Leonard Lichfield, Printer to the Vniversity. 1645.

div.head: THE REFUSERS OF PEACE VNEXCVSABLE.
In Answer to a Libell against His MAjESTIES late Messages for PEACE.
div.p:
WHen I read His Majesties late gratious Messages for a safe Conduct, for some few Persons of Honour and integrity, to goe up to London with Propositions for the Peace of this Kingdome, Methought in this Conjuncture of time, nothing could be more seasonable; for it seemed to me a point of time, that had freed all those Persons of Jealousies and Feares, who at first, as well had them as pretended them. Nor could I doubt that they that had so often sworn Allegiance to, and profest so long they endeavoured nothing, but a good understanding with their Soveraigne, should now decline it, when they were thus fairely offered so hopefull a meanes to attaine it. But th ugh I understand of Answers to those Messages, which fall farre short of my beliefe as well as hope; yet I will give no censure upon them, because I see, they are still in agitation betwixt His Majesty and the two Houses: And that His Majesty by later Messages (wherein he offers (being secured) to goe up to London, and Treat with His English and Scotch Subjects there, and to secure all
men by granting, an equall Militia, to give satisfaction concerning the businesse of Ireland, to have consideration of the Publique debts to the Scots, Citty of London, and others,) Outdoes all example, that he might divert the present felt, and threatning miseries of this Kingdome. So as I had been silent, had nor some Scandalous Pamphlets made it their ayme to deface those Actions, which so lively expresse His Majesties tender and Fatherly care of His Kingdomes, nay, to defame His Person by it.

Did I think that this venome came only from the heart and putrified entralls of him that belches it out, I should neglect it, but looking upon him only as the pitts mouth, that breaths out the infectious and killing ayre, which the deadly minerall of the soyle evaporates; I cannot but warne all persons that are given over to believe a lye, to draw farre off from this contagion. When he saies so disloyally, as well as unmannerly C. R. is come to Towne againe. He knowes what it is to bring a Kings Person or Writing in contempt: if he can but gaine you to make slight of so sober a Subject, he hath half wonne you to swallow downe all his inconsequent and fallatious arguments. Next to this (O shame that in a Christian Common-wealth it should be permitted) He can tell you, There is talke of Conscience, and Bloodshed, and dreadfull day of Judgement, and Peace at Oxford, (which he saies,) is not so much there as dreamt on: Nay at first he seems to have the modesty to decline the application thereof personally to the King, for he expresses it, They at Oxford never dreame of these things, and yet (without playing the Pharisee, as to bragge) from my Consciences I averre it; most there, are of those, that are both faithfull and peaceable in the Land, and if Martyrdome be to be their Crowne, for it will not decline it; yet presently with one breath he is at this.
Doe you think C. R. dreamt of a day of Judgement, when the mercifull Commission past the Seale for Ireland?

Yes, He did: for you know, the meanes of maintaining that Warre being diverted for the raising this; in how desperate and deplorable condition, His Protestant Subjects were there; And how this was represented to him, by all the Persons intrusted with that government, (and such as had no tincture of complying with the Rebells) before He made any Cessation.
Doe you think he dreamt of a day of Judgement, when the deep Protestations were sent abroad from Yorke?

Yes, He did: And for that you know, he sent you the hands of some Lords now among you, who with the rest endeavoured to assure you the same, and are grown as bad as your selfe, if they will not declare in their Conscience they believed it.
Doe you think &c. When the Standard first flourisht at Nottingham?

Yes, He did: Can you remember that time, and not what equall and Peaceable Propositions you then rejected, which if then accepted, had saved all this blood-shed. Was not the Standard then effered to be taken downe, and Proclamations that gave some their due appellations of Traitors, to be called in, if you would have done the like, and the King upon this to returne to you?
Doe you think &c, When the Mock-Treaty was so hotly pursued at Ʋxbridge?

Yes, sure He did. For did not His Majesty give an unlimited and concluding power to his Commissioners, whilest yours confest they had none? Did He not make great condescentions and offers, whilest you met Him in nothing? Did He not desire to prolong the Treaty, whilest you made as much hast to break it off? Did He not publish His proceedings therein to all the World, in so plain a way, being all matter of Fact, that when the avenger of blood shall make Inquisition, it will be found you have been guilty of all that hath been spilt? And did not this convince you? yes, sure it did, for you never answered the same, though now almost twelve months since it was written.

I have in all these particulars given you not above one instance, because in severall Tracts with many serious Arguments, His Majesties Actions have been manifested and justified agai • st all Opposers, for me thinkes a little paines may discover the falsities of your arguments: For truly I would not slight them, not mistake them willingly; But in earnest, I doe, if this be not the whole reasoning (I'le not say rayling) that is in them.
The King would never condescend wholly to all the two Houses offored him, (I will not now question the nature of the Propositions, whether good or bad) Therefore He never intended a Peace.
Now take the Reverse, and turne this Argument as it is true in Fact.

The King and the two Houses differed upon divers new (remember that) things, which tended to the alteration of the present Government; And to compose this, the King was ever willing to a Treaty, The Houses but sometimes; The King would ever have prolonged the time of Treating, The Houses not; The King made many considerable Condescentions and Complyings, The Houses none: Let any man make the Conclusion, which of these two most truly sought the Peace of the Kingdome.

To all this adde, The King never desired a new thing, The Houses scarce any thing that was not an Innovation in the State; The King never denyed any part of Old Magna Charta, (indeed it was become as much His Security as the Subjects) The two Houses, without they might have a Power over King, Lawes, and People, would not be content: The King, though He had granted more then all His Predecessors, desired not to retract any one Law, but to confirme all; whil'st the Houses with an hydropicall humour, aske more, because they had obtained much: The King never unwilling to Treat with them upon any of their demands, Nay, willing to condescend to any thing more then He had already granted, if in Reason and Conscience He could; (For doe but remember how He extended His former Graces, by His new Offers to your Nineteen Propositions) And the Houses would not be content, unlesse He unmanned Himselfe, to agree to that which in reason He could not; He un-Christianned Himselfe, to act that, which in Conscience He could not; unlesse He dethroned Himselfe, and wholly to transferre that Power to others, which God had placed in Himselfe: And because they were made for His Helpers, therefore they must be admitted to be Sole Rulers, or make a Warre.
You talke of a Tribunall, but thinke now, how dreadfull that place will be to you, and all your Disciples, that thus Slander, or give credit to the Slanders, cast upon the Lords Annointed.

I have done with this Railer, The Lord convert, or rebuke him, and turne his Counsell into folly, for I look upon his Spirit (let it dwell in him, or in others, and he only the Pipe to convey it) like
that of Achitophels; The whole designe being to make the breach so great, Absalom and David, the King and his People, may never meet. But God that defeated that Counsell, will. I doubt not, this, and so prosper his faithfull, though afflicted Servant, the King, That the King shall returne, nay that Israel, shall be angry they fetcht him not in first.

I have spun this Discourse longer then I intended; but however before I conclude, I desire all Persons, that have power to contribute to a good Intelligence betwixt the King and His People, would consider, whether there be not likely to be such a disunion in Opinion in your new intended Forme of Government, both in Church and State, as if the present were destroyed, would not create a new Warre: Whether, if it can be so tempered at present, that Lot and Abraham may set forth in journing together, for the diversity and multitude of opinions, their Heards-men are not soon like to be quarrelling: Whether, if Ireland should be forced to give it selfe over to a Forraigner, the youth and wealth of this Kingdome may not too likely be buried there: Nay, whether thi • their subjection to a Forraigner, may not introduce a Forraigne Warre into this Kingdome, which is so farre spent already by a Civill: Whether all these differences are not likelier to be composed by an obedience to the King, according to the ancient Lawes of the Land, in whose Authority all differing interests doe concernter, then in any new forme or usurpation: Consider whether Zimri had Peace, that slew his Master; whether to destroy our Head, be our way to make our Body thrive. At least, I warne all disinteressed Persons, not to suck in this poysenous Doctrine, That Successe is the Seale, God markes His with, when Christs distinction of his Flock is Affliction; For thus we may preferre Mahomet before Christ, since the Turke thrives even at present against the Christians. I professe I desire my Portion rather out of the Cup of Persecution, then the intoxicating liquor of a fortunate Rebellion, which is only so termed, because the men of the present Age, seeme to have the Lordship over their Opposers, and the fat of the spoyle: But how fatall such Successes were to Gods, and hath been to all People in their Posterity, all Histories both holy and prophane doe testifie. Nor doe you know any people, that
were driven to practise it, and who took it up for their remedy, that are not enforced to a constant Warre; And to pay yearly twenty times more out of their annuall Revenue, then ever you paid to a King of England. Call to mind this Kingdomes burthens this last five yeares. Well, whatever is the Intention of the best Patriots, it is not in the wisedome of any of them to foresee the sad disorders of such an absolute change they endeavour. Consider, whether it be possible to admit such a Change, and that there is not an equall necessity to have all secured by constant Garrisons and Squadrons of Horse in every County, to rule (as I may say) a new Conquered People, for so are you, when old Lawes are changed by Force; And whether five yeares since, though some then murmured, the Christian world accounted you not a free, rich, and happy People; And whether, upon the Government by the present Lawes of this Kingdome, you were not so, successively 500. yeares together, some usuall intertuptions admitted. It is not likely, but the feare of the Invasion of a Stranger, or imbred differences, will keep you in a constant servitude to your new Militia & Rulers. No remedy against any part of this, but Reunion with our Head the King, so may every man returne to his owne Vineyard; And without this, so uncertaine will your Peace be, That he will be least likely to reap the Fruit who Sowes the Seed. God therefore give a blessing, to what His Majesty hath so gratiously proposed: And let the mouth of all Slanderers and detracters be stopt, That we may no longer shed the bloud of Warre in the time of Peace.
